snippet.textDisplay: Semantics time ... The answer kind of depends of where you are.  You "weigh" more in America but you "weigh" less in England.  In America we use pounds, which is a measurement of the the pull of gravity.  England uses metric which measures weight in grams which is a measurement of mass.  So in metric you lose mass and in America you gain in the pull of gravity.  Like I said, semantics.
snippet.textOriginal: Semantics time ... The answer kind of depends of where you are.  You "weigh" more in America but you "weigh" less in England.  In America we use pounds, which is a measurement of the the pull of gravity.  England uses metric which measures weight in grams which is a measurement of mass.  So in metric you lose mass and in America you gain in the pull of gravity.  Like I said, semantics.

snippet.textDisplay: I got it right mid way :) Thank you Mark

snippet.textDisplay:
Doesn't the internal pressure affect the density of the fart?
Answer: Yes, but not enough.

I assumed the pressure inside the lower intestine would have a significant effect on the density of the gas. An hour of research and fiddling with the ideal gas law revealed that it does, but not enough. The gas inside the body has a higher temperature than the gas surrounding us. This reduces the density significantly. The pressure of the fart required to balance the higher temperature would be just short of 1 psi, which is about five times the actual pressure I could find.
A higher humidity of the gas inside the intestine would actually further reduce the density of the gas, if only slightly.
The only argument I could find against clue 3 is the composition of the fart. The gas is a mixture of air, light gases (hydrogen, methane) and heavy gases (CO2). The ratio is different for the individual person, diet and situation. In special cases, a fart might actually make you weigh less, but generally, it does not.
snippet.textOriginal:
Doesn't the internal pressure affect the density of the fart?
Answer: Yes, but not enough.

I assumed the pressure inside the lower intestine would have a significant effect on the density of the gas. An hour of research and fiddling with the ideal gas law revealed that it does, but not enough. The gas inside the body has a higher temperature than the gas surrounding us. This reduces the density significantly. The pressure of the fart required to balance the higher temperature would be just short of 1 psi, which is about five times the actual pressure I could find.
A higher humidity of the gas inside the intestine would actually further reduce the density of the gas, if only slightly.
The only argument I could find against clue 3 is the composition of the fart. The gas is a mixture of air, light gases (hydrogen, methane) and heavy gases (CO2). The ratio is different for the individual person, diet and situation. In special cases, a fart might actually make you weigh less, but generally, it does not.

snippet.textDisplay: The total mass of a fart is 0.0371 grams. Farts weigh 1.3 grams per liter. Our average fart contained 1/28th of a liter of gas, and that would work out to 0.0464 grams.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think an important thing that you forgot (I think) is that the fart gets replaced with air because I think it's save to assume the volume of a person stays the same.

Its like a balloon made of metal that's leaking helium and taking in air. Because just leaking heluim would not change the boincy.

This is an important difference as it now seems that you can weigh more just by letting letting go of stuff but it's actually the changing of volume (in the case of a normal helium balloon that is leaking) or the replacing it with something that is more massive(in case of a fart) Wich is causing you to weigh more.

One could even make the argument that the void that gets created by farting just causes the rest of the gasses in you to expand and there for you would actually weigh les.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Why is the Sky blue?
Blue light has the highest frequency of visible light. So it wobbles the most and bumps into the most air molecules. This way it scatters more than other colors of light.
snippet.textOriginal:
Why is the Sky blue?
Blue light has the highest frequency of visible light. So it wobbles the most and bumps into the most air molecules. This way it scatters more than other colors of light.

snippet.textDisplay: The sky is blue, because the color blue is scattered more than any other color. Blue travels in shorter waves. But, the ocean is blue for sort of the same reason. White light (from the sun) blue is the color that mostly gets returned. Which is also why the sky is blue.
snippet.textOriginal: The sky is blue, because the color blue is scattered more than any other color. Blue travels in shorter waves. But, the ocean is blue for sort of the same reason. White light (from the sun) blue is the color that mostly gets returned. Which is also why the sky is blue.

snippet.textDisplay:
5 days into quarantine
Mark: Does Farting Make You Weigh Less?
snippet.textOriginal:
5 days into quarantine
Mark: Does Farting Make You Weigh Less?

snippet.textDisplay:
While I agree with your points along the way, I'm not sure I'm convinced by your conclusion, Mark.

Could it be the case that Farts are compressed and expelling them doesn't appreciably reduce our volume, other trapped gasses just expand to fill the gap and become less dense. Thus you weigh less when you fart because your volume has stayed the same but your mass has decreased. Measuring by how much might be more than a little tricky though. Like measuring a persons volume.
snippet.textOriginal:
While I agree with your points along the way, I'm not sure I'm convinced by your conclusion, Mark.

Could it be the case that Farts are compressed and expelling them doesn't appreciably reduce our volume, other trapped gasses just expand to fill the gap and become less dense. Thus you weigh less when you fart because your volume has stayed the same but your mass has decreased. Measuring by how much might be more than a little tricky though. Like measuring a persons volume.

snippet.textDisplay: Objection: by expelling the methane and sulfates of your fart you are decreasing your overall mass, thereby lowering your weight (imperceptibly). Moreover, the force involved with the fart action itself applies a directional force via Newton's second law, so when you fart, you actually push against the air and the Earth VERY SLIGHTLY and for a moment resist gravity a bit more.
snippet.textOriginal: Objection: by expelling the methane and sulfates of your fart you are decreasing your overall mass, thereby lowering your weight (imperceptibly). Moreover, the force involved with the fart action itself applies a directional force via Newton's second law, so when you fart, you actually push against the air and the Earth VERY SLIGHTLY and for a moment resist gravity a bit more.

snippet.textDisplay: DEAR GOD, PLEASE switch away from using a 1080i camera and then changing it to 1080p with a horrible codec. Please just use a 1080p camera right out of the gate and leave it all at 1080p. All of the weird staggered horizontal lines comes from the differences from the change in FIELDS and FRAMES from the change from Interlaced (1080i) and Progressive (YouTube video files and computer screens)
snippet.textOriginal: DEAR GOD, PLEASE switch away from using a 1080i camera and then changing it to 1080p with a horrible codec. snippet.textDisplay: I certainly buy that farts outside the body are less dense than air. Methane and hydrogen are much less dense than air but farts also contain more c02 than air which is much more dense than air. In fact, c02 is the heaviest gas found in air in higher than trace amounts (even though there is only about 0.03% c02 in our atmosphere.) The difference in density between farts and air, I would presume, comes largely from difference in temperature. Is that difference enough to counteract any pressure from your innards? Does farting when it is over 100 degrees outside make you heavier or lighter? I dunno.
snippet.textOriginal: I certainly buy that farts outside the body are less dense than air. Methane and hydrogen are much less dense than air but farts also contain more c02 than air which is much more dense than air. In fact, c02 is the heaviest gas found in air in higher than trace amounts (even though there is only about 0.03% c02 in our atmosphere.) The difference in density between farts and air, I would presume, comes largely from difference in temperature. Is that difference enough to counteract any pressure from your innards? Does farting when it is over 100 degrees outside make you heavier or lighter? I dunno.

snippet.textDisplay: I disagree with Mark's answer. Weight is irrelevant to buoyancy. Weight is equal to the gravitational force something pulls on another object. When you fart you lose mass which means the earth does not pull on you as much which means you lose weight. Your  buoyancy does go up but that is irrelevant when talking about weight. If you put something in a vacuum chamber it does not change its weight. Buoyancy will not push up on it but that will not change its weight. On a planet's surface where the gravity is pretty even everywhere a change in mass causes a change in weight. Mark is talking about the net force of weight and buoyancy.  At least this is what I was taught in school.
snippet.textOriginal: I disagree with Mark's answer. Weight is irrelevant to buoyancy. Weight is equal to the gravitational force something pulls on another object. When you fart you lose mass which means the earth does not pull on you as much which means you lose weight. Your  buoyancy does go up but that is irrelevant when talking about weight. If you put something in a vacuum chamber it does not change its weight. Buoyancy will not push up on it but that will not change its weight. On a planet's surface where the gravity is pretty even everywhere a change in mass causes a change in weight. Mark is talking about the net force of weight and buoyancy.  At least this is what I was taught in school.

to begin, the sunlight is actually white and its the interaction between the color wave lengths and the atmosphere causing it to appear yellow.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a physics science teacher myself and I'd say this is somewhat misleading unless some terminology is better defined.  If in your question, "weigh" is meant as what you would weigh on a scale, or what we call "apparent weight," then yes, you are correct.  Since a scale doesn't actually read the force of gravity on you but rather the force it exerts on you, it takes the difference between your actual weight and buoyant force which is usually negligible in most situations.  However, if in your question, "weigh" is meant to be the actual "weight," or commonly defined as the force of gravity on you, then your assessment is incorrect because there is now less force of gravity on you.  So a more accurate defining of terms is important here.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a physics science teacher myself and I'd say this is somewhat misleading unless some terminology is better defined.  If in your question, "weigh" is meant as what you would weigh on a scale, or what we call "apparent weight," then yes, you are correct.  Since a scale doesn't actually read the force of gravity on you but rather the force it exerts on you, it takes the difference between your actual weight and buoyant force which is usually negligible in most situations.  However, if in your question, "weigh" is meant to be the actual "weight," or commonly defined as the force of gravity on you, then your assessment is incorrect because there is now less force of gravity on you.  So a more accurate defining of terms is important here.
